title: Patrick Modiano wins the Nobel prize in literature 2014 â as it happened | Books | The Guardian
summary: modiano gives his first interview after winning the award .
critic catherine taylor on patrick modiano .
patrick modiano wins the nobel prize in literature .

text: that 's all from our live blog .
thanks for following us .
stay tuned to the books site for more on this most unexpected of nobel winners .

documents.title: modiano gives his first interview after winning the award
text: patrick modiano 's first telephone interview since winning the prize has just been published on the nobel prize website .
he explained that he heard the news in a phone call from his daughter while he was out walking in paris : i was very moved , he said .
asked what it meant to him to be a nobel laureate , he choked up with emotion : i never thought this would happen to me , it has truly touched me .
he said he had started writing when he was very young : it 's something that 's been part of my life since the beginning .

he declined to recommend a particular book to readers unfamiliar with his work , saying he had the impression of having been continually writing the same one in a discontinued way , over 45 years : it 's as if i stopped to take a break , and then continued with the next stage of the same book .
modiano also confirmed that he is going to be in stockholm in december to receive the prize , together with his family he has two daughters and one grandson , to whom he dedicated the award .
here is the audio of the interview , in french :
news of his nobel win has finally reached modiano : he was in a restaurant with his wife eating lunch when he heard that he had won .
he was very happy and laughed and his wife cried with joy , said his spokersperson , pascale richard to swedish public broadcaster svt .
the times literary supplement has been riffling through its archives : thetls ( @ thetls ) our reviews of patrick modiano 's work - freely available here :
if any of you speak french and want to hear it from the horse 's mouth , here is a clip where modiano talks about his novel dans le cafã© de la jeunesse perdue :
michael wood reviewed modiano 's the search warrant for the london review of books in 2000 .
he wrote : much recurs in modiano 's work , then , and the range is not vast .
but the novels i 've read the recent ones are subtly , even insidiously different from each other .
you think you know where you are , because the places are similar and the natives look alike .
this is an error , because they are all about loss , and scrupulously , painfully remind us that no two losses are the same .
modiano is a kind of marcel proust for our time , rewinding backwards , according to nobel 's peter englund , as reported in the luxemburger wort .

the paper has some more biographical detail : he was born at the end of world war ii , on july 30 , 1945 , in the paris suburb of boulogne into a family whose complex background set the scene for a lifelong obsession with that dark period in history .
his father , alberto modiano , was an italian jew with ties to the gestapo who did not have to wear the yellow star and who was also close to organised crime gangs .
his mother was a flemish actress named louisa colpeyn .
published when he was just 22 , in 1967 , his first novel la place de l'etoile ( the star 's place ) , was a direct reference to the mark of shame inflicted on the jews .
in 1972 , modiano was awarded the french academy 's grand prize for his novel ring roads , and the goncourt prize in 1978 for missing person .
in 1996 , he won the national literature grand prize for his entire work .
patrick modiano in 1977. des archives/louis monier/rue des archives/writer pictures

modiano 's uk publisher has just been in touch to say : harvill secker published modiano 's the search warrant ( translated by joanna kilmartin ) in 2000 , and it is currently available in ebook and paperback ( and we are reprinting !
if you want to know more , here is our first news story on modiano 's win more news and comment to come later .
more from modiano 's le figaro interview : he says he found writing awful when he was younger .
recently i looked back at my first manuscripts and was struck by the lack of space , of breath .
that 's exactly how it felt , back then ¦ like i was suffocating .
while the tension is less acute these days , he continues , he does n't feel as if he 's made much progress .
for a long time i 've had a recurring dream i dream i do n't have to write any more , that i 'm free .
i 'm not free , alas , i 'm still clearing the same terrain , with the impression that it 's never finished .
spanish novelist enrique vila-matas praised modiano in an el paã­s feature back in 2012 .

here are some of his words : modiano has worked hard his whole life to go deep into the complexity of the past and the vagueness of any identity , always with the style of a private investigator , of a constant inquirer into the hidden and the sombre .
the gloomy side of his books seems to always reveal itself as one slowly advances in the reading .

there are moments of discouragement , as if we were driving a very slow racing car without any visibility and without knowing if we are at the border of a cliff or that of a motorway , but that gives it all an uncertain and attractive touch .
in the world of modiano , everything always happens in the past , although sometimes it 's a yesterday that looks very similar to the present .
vila-matas also wrote about modiano 's love for paris : today we know that , since his earliest wonders around paris , modiano was impressed forever by the city .
all his work is in fact the work of a desperate man who ca n't live without paris .
a man who is overcome by a brutal love , completely crazy , for the city , for the neighbourhoods that he saw as a young man .
and he quoted the french writer saying this about the city : it 's not about nostalgia , believe me , it 's a timeless paris .
for me paris has always been something internal .
more coming to light about modiano all the time .

the film database imdb records that he is not only a fairly prolific screenwriter for both film and tv , but an actor , who appeared alongside catherine deneuve in the 1997 raoul ruiz film genealogies of a crime , playing a character called bob .
he did n't get star billing .
oh yes , and according to imdb he 's 6 ' 6tall

documents.title: critic catherine taylor on patrick modiano
text: guardian critic and deputy director of pen catherine taylor is a fan of modiano , and has written us a short appreciation : patrick modiano , winner of the 2014 nobel prize in literature .
helie/ap in 1988 french-jewish writer patrick modiano was sifting through some documents relating to the occupation when he came across a notice in paris soir on new year 's eve , 1941 .
it was a description of a missing 17-year-old girl , placed there by her parents .
dora bruder was jewish and had been hidden in a convent for safety - from where she had , it seems , simply disappeared .
the next mention of dora bruder was on a list of deportees from the internment camp at drancy , who were then deported to auschwitz .

these scraps of information proved justification enough for modiano , who is jewish-italian on his father 's side , to begin his own investigation into the girl 's fate , published in english as the search warrant by harvill in 2000 , translated by joanna kilmartin .
a truly impressive sifter of apparent ephemera , modiano pieces together newspaper cuttings , vague testimonies and old telephone directories .
he looks intently at the outsider living on the outskirts of a city , usually paris .

regarding dora bruder , he writes : i shall never know how she spent her days , where she hid , in whose company she passed the winter months of her first escape , or the few weeks of spring when she escaped for the second time .
that is her secret . '
modiano 's quiet , austere novels , which also include night moves , read like compassionate , regretful thrillers .
that is his secret .
here are some reactions on social media .

we could say they are clearly divided between those who have never heard of modiano making mostly bad wikipedia jokes , as one tweeter pointed out and those who proudly did know about the french writer and need to show the world .

there is a lot of twitter buzz coming from france ( obviously ) , italy and spain , where the writer was widely translated and better known than in english-speaking countries : michael balter ( @ mbalter ) the # nobel watchers do n't seem to have been expecting a french guy to win .
# modiano very popular in # france james poniewozik ( @ poniewozik ) what 's the french word for `` huh '' ?
# nobel martin wilson ( @ martinwilson73 ) another frenchie ?
that i 've never heard of ?
quite the comedown from the munro win last year .
# nobel steven toribio ( @ steventoribio ) googles patrick modiano such a great decision !
totally deserved .
i have read all his stuff , except those i have n't , meaning all .
# nobel animaol ( @ hoogueeto ) - parra ?
- no , this is patrick - murakami ?
- no , this is patrick !
- kundera ?
- no , this is patrick # nobel
alison flood writes : yale university press is publishing suspended sentences , a collection of three novellas by modiano , translated by mark polizzotti , next year .
the blurb says : modiano draws on his own experiences , blended with the real or invented stories of others , to present a dreamlike autobiography that is also the biography of a place .
pour que tu ne te perdes pas dans le quartier by patrick modiano , winner of the 2014 nobel prize in literature .
roland/afp/getty images his most recent novel , pour que tu ne te perdes pas dans le quartier ( so you do n't get lost in the neighbourhood ) , has just been published in france by gallimard .
its description runs : one day , two strangers who claim to have found the address book of the writer jean daragane insist on meeting him .
daragne agrees to a meeting and finds himself despite himself getting embroiled in the investigation these two young people are conducting about a certain guy torstel and the child ?
asked daragne .
have you had news of the child ?
nothing .

i 've often asked myself what became of him here 's a bit from claire devarrieux 's review of pour que tu ne te perdes pas dans le quartier in libã©ration : the writer jean daragane has n't seen anyone for three months , so when someone calls to say they 've found his address book at the gare de lyon he arranges a meeting .

a young girl called chantal gives daragane a dossier containing his first novel , some more-or-less-illegible papers and some passport photos of a little boy : this child , held by the decades at such a distance that he was a stranger , he had to admit that it was him . '
from echo to coincidence , the writer goes back to the source , the anguish of a child who is afraid of being abandoned in an empty house .
how can you avoid thinking that here is the source of modiano 's work and art ?
gallimard have just tweeted : une rã©compense qui consacre une oeuvre littã©raire limpide et magnifique !
( a recognition which marks a clear and magnificent literary career ! )
gallimard ( @ gallimard ) le prix # nobel de littã©rature est dã©cernã© ã. patrick modiano .
une rã©compense qui consacre une oeuvre littã©raire limpide et magnifique !
the publisher added on facebook : l'oeuvre de patrick modiano vient d'ãªtre rã©compensã©e par le prix nobel de littã©rature 2014 .

nous sommes immensã©ment fiers d'accompagner cet immense ã©crivain , auteur d'une oeuvre dã©licate et limpide.we are incredibly proud of accompanying this important writer , author of a delicate and clear work .
the nobel committee have n't managed to track modiano down yet to tell him about his win .

here 's an interview with him from france today : you 'll never stumble upon him at one of those literary cocktail parties parisian editors adore , nor will you spy his rangy figure on popular talk shows .
modiano 's interviews are few , but his words are priceless his wife opens the door , but there 's no mistaking the famous silhouette in the background , looking like an awkward giant .

with disarming kindness , he ushers you into his office , a vast room packed with antique furniture and endless bookshelvesmainly essays on wartime , in both french and english.after each novel , i have the impression that i have cleared it all away , he says between two silences .
but i know i 'll come back over and over again to tiny details , little things that are part of what i am .
in the end , we are all determined by the place and the time in which we were born .
after each novel , i have the impression that i have cleared it all away , he says between two silences .
but i know i 'll come back over and over again to tiny details , little things that are part of what i am .
in the end , we are all determined by the place and the time in which we were born .
in a 2012 interview with the french newspaper le figaro , he compared writing to driving in fog .
you do n't know where you 're going , you just know you have to go on
modiano has been translated into english by joanna kilmartin .

reviewing one of his novels , honeymoon , in 20011 , novelist rupert thompson wrote : this slippery , atmospheric hall-of-mirrors effect is classic modiano modiano is a jackdaw when it comes to genre .
he steals from the spy novel and detective fiction - film noir too - but what interests him in the end is the gaps in people 's lives , the bits that can never be accounted for .

documents.title: peter englund describes modiano 's work
text: peter englund , permanent secretary of the swedish academy , says : modiano is a french author who was born in france 1945 , he has written some 30 different books , mainly novels , but also a number of childrens ' books , movie scripts .
[ his novels ] are small books , 130 , 150 pages , which are always variations of the same theme - memory , loss , identity , seeking .
he is well known in france but pretty well not anywhere else he has been translated more into swedish than english .
i can recommend missing person .
he is very fond of the detective genre and he plays with it .
it is a story about a detective who has lost his memory and his final case is finding out who he really is , he is tracing his own steps through history to find out who he is .
it 's a fun book - playing with the genre , still saying something very fundamental about memory and time .
as a person concerned with memory , which i think we all are - he has a very special art of memory , how it works .
he is sort of possessed about his attempts to reach back in time , and you can identify yourself with these attempts , and his very original ways to do it .

documents.title: patrick modiano wins the nobel prize in literature
text: and the winner is patrick modiano .
he 's 69 years old and the 13th french writer to win .
refresh the page to watch the announcement live above .
ian rankin - who does n't make the odds anywhere , sadly - has just tweeted : fellow writers !
nobel prize for literature announced today !
everyone sitting by their phones ? i wonder if those believed to be contenders are sitting , waiting for a call - or just getting on with things , a la doris lessing ?
best appearance of an artichoke in a literary video ever
alison flood writes : here 's a nice stat from the nobel crew : sorted by genre , there have been 76 prose winners , 33 poetry winners , 14 drama , three philosophy/essay writing , and two history .
what does that tell us ?
well , in recent years we 've had short stories from alice munro , fiction from mo yan , poetry from tomas transtromer , a bit of everything from mario vargas llosa and herta muller .
time for a dramatist ?
ngugi is a playwright !
ngugi wa thiong'o ¦ could his theatre record tip the vote ?
macleod

here are some of the wishes , predictions ( and random conjectures ) coming in on twitter from around the world : pranabkrbhattacharya ( @ profpkbkr ) # nobelprize2014 i predicted this year nobel prize for literature will go to milan kundera setareh sabety ( @ setarehsabety ) i want # magaretattwood to win # nobelprize2014 in # literature hide satoh ( @ hdsth ) @ hirokotabuchi @ twitterid my bet is svetlana alexievich , belarus .
david hebblethwaite ( @ david heb ) imagine the cognitive dissonance if ryu murakami were awarded the nobel .
the excitement is building ( well , at a dignified pace ) the nobel prize ( @ nobelprize ) people are gathering at the @ twitterid to watch the announcement of # nobelprize2014 in literature .
the nobel prize ( @ nobelprize ) for the # nobelprize2014 in literature , the swedish academy has received 210 valid nominations , among them , 36 are first time nominees .
the nobel prize ( @ nobelprize ) the major broad casters are already in place .
announcement of # nobelprize2014 in literature at 1 p.m cet .
time magazine and the new republic tell us not to bother looking at the latest odds for the nobel , because they 're almost always wrong .

perhaps the bookies ' favourite does n't win , but the name of the eventual winner is usually circulating near the top of the odds - and often makes a surprise race to the top in the days/hours before the announcement .
i remember herta muller did exactly this back in 2009 , meaning i 'd had time to read a little about her just before she was announced as winner .
this year , it 's been all about haruki murakami and ngugi wa thiong'o - either of them fantastic winners ( but i 'd prefer the kenyan writer ) .
belarusian writer svetlana alexievich is the most unfamiliar name ( to me at least ) in the bookies ' top contenders - could that mean it 's her year ?
alison flood could it be svetlana alekseievitch 's year ?
andersen/getty images
alison flood writes : philip roth 's name always comes up as a possible .

asked by the new york times if being an eternal candidate bothered him earlier this year , he was ty incisive : i wonder if i had called portnoy 's complaint the orgasm under rapacious capitalism , if i would thereby have earned the favor of the swedish academy .
fabulous .
and yes , he 'd be wonderful .
but i do n't think it 's going to happen .
he 's retired from writing - i wake up in the morning , get a big glass of orange juice and read for an hour and a half .
i 've never done that in my life , he said last january - and the nobel tends to reward writers who are still at it .
plus , an american , the year after a canadian won it ?
unlikely .
but i 'd be delighted to be proved wrong hope springs eternal ?
¦ philip roth thayer/reuters

returning to nationality , here 's a colourful illustration of winners by country , which was up by our colleagues over on the science team reuters world ( @ reutersworld ) which country has the most nobel prizes ?
find out in today 's data dive :
to many nobel watchers , the gender ratio is as revealing as that of nationality , as guardian commenter elizabeth yake made clear .
elizabeth yake 09 october 2014 9:40am where the heck are the women ?
quite so , elizabeth .

of the 110 nobel prizes in literature awarded so far , 13 have been to women , according to the academy 's own site , though that figure of just over 10 % is higher than the overall ratio for the five medals .

in all , there are 45 female laureates in a total of 876 for the record , the female literature laureates are : 1909 - selma lagerlã¶f 1926 - grazia deledda 1928 - sigrid undset 1938 - pearl buck 1945 - gabriela mistral 1966 - nelly sachs 1991 - nadine gordimer 1993 - toni morrison 1996 - wislawa szymborska 2004 - elfriede jelinek 2007 - doris lessing 2009 - herta mã¼ller 2013 - alice munro

the leaks and hoaxes of previous years have been notably absent this year , though the more holmesian among nobel watchers may be detecting clues in academy member horace engdahl 's recent pronouncement that western writers had succumbed to a dependency culture of grants and creative writing courses .
when reading many writers from asia and africa , one finds a certain liberty again , he said .
here , from the nobel 's own website , is a revealing interactive showing the distribution of existing nobel laureates in all disciplines by country of birth .
there are more from tasmania than from most of africa .
distribution of nobel laureates by country , from the nobel website click here to go into the interactive :

in his will announcing the endowment of five new prizes , alfred nobel dedicated the fourth to the person who shall have produced in the field of literature the most outstanding work in an ideal direction it 's a mission statement that has produced a motley crew of winners ever since first prize was awarded in 1901 to the french poet and essayist sully prudhomme , to the dismay of many who felt tolstoy should have been a shoe-in .

cries of jubilation - and no little relief - echoed around the anglophone world when last year 's award went to the canadian short story writer alice munro , whose chosen form is felt by many to have robbed her of her dues as one of its finest fiction writers .

a good winner alice munro press/rex speculation about the likely winner of the 2014 award - due to be announced at 12noon bst today - has been mounting steadily , with philip roth making a late surge to challenge the kenyan writer ngugi wa thiong'o and the perennially tipped japanese novelist haruki murakami in the betting odds .
a guardian reader poll of the 10 frontrunners currently has 36 % rooting for murakami , with roth in second place at 28 % .
the poll closes at 12noon , so vote for your favourite now .
in a recent guardian interview , 65-year-old murakami complained : i 'm a kind of outcast of the japanese literary world .
i have my own readers ¦ but critics , writers , many of them do n't like me .
time alone can tell whether the wise heads of the swedish academy share that opinion .
the perennial outsider ?

haruki murakami macleod murakami could at least console himself that he 's in good company - not only of tolstoy but of moomin creator tove jansson , who philip pullman recently argued was one of the nobel 's great should-have-beens .

bulletin.text: 69-year-old Modiano is cited by the Swedish Academy for the art of memory with which he has evoked the most ungraspable human destinies and uncovered the life-world of the occupation'
An appreciation and top five Modiano must-reads.
